rows.text_1:
Today's lesson is about helping our children follow instructions and rules by using consequences

Consequences are the results of actions and behaviours. Parents can use a planned consequence when children don’t follow a rule or instruction. 

For example if a child doesn’t follow the rule to come home from playing at 6pm, then a consequence could be that the child can’t go out to play the next day. 

Giving clear consequences teaches children that their actions affect themselves and others.
rows.media_title: How will it help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
We all misbehave sometimes! 

As parents, we are also sometimes tempted to scream and shout when our children misbehave. But that just makes everything worse for everyone.

If we stay calm and give our children a consequence instead, they start to learn to take responsibility for their actions and we avoid the anger that comes with hitting or shouting.

rows.text_1:
Some consequences happen naturally (if they break a toy, they cannot play with it). 

Other consequences you will set. These consequences will help your child follow the rules (if you do not pack away your toys, you won’t be allowed to play with them tomorrow).

rows.text_1: Here are some easy steps to use consequences when your child misbehaves:
rows.section_1_text:
Take some deep breaths or walk away from the situation if you need to.

Then, respond in a calm, clear way.
rows.section_1_extra_text: Shouting at our children only makes things worse. It also teaches them that it is okay to treat others like this when they are upset.
rows.section_2_text:
Before giving a consequence, give your child the choice to behave and time to do what you asked.

Give a consequence connected to the behaviour, and make sure it is something you can follow through with.
rows.section_2_extra_text:
For example, if they do not clean up their toys, they cannot play with them the next day (rather than the whole week).

If your child is experiencing a natural consequence for their action already (like not being able to play with their toy after breaking it), you might not need to give them an additional consequence.
rows.section_3_text:
It is important to follow through with consequences for the rules you have set, every time they do not follow them.

This helps your child to know what to expect, and makes it more likely that they will follow the rule.
rows.section_3_extra_text: Talk about consequences for breaking household rules when you create these rules, so that your child knows them and sticks to them.
rows.section_4_text: Involve your children in planning consequences for certain behaviours.
rows.section_4_extra_text: Discuss what a consequence could be if children do not follow a certain household rule when they are creating it with them.

rows.text_1: Let’s come up with some ideas for reasonable and realistic consequences.
rows.quiz_1_question: Would any of these consequences be helpful for you and your child?
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: If you are late for dinner, your food will be cold.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: If you continue splashing water out of the bath, bath time will be over.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: If you break your toy, you will have no toy to play with.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.
rows.quiz_1_option_4_text: If you can’t play close to home where I can see you, then you will have to come inside.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.
rows.quiz_1_option_5_text: If you do not put away your toys before you go to bed, then you cannot play with them tomorrow morning.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_5: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out tomorrow.
rows.quiz_1_option_6_text: None of these will work in my home.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_6: That's okay! Try to think of just one consequence that you feel confident you can follow-through with in a calm way. Try starting with something small.

rows.text_1:
Remember that praising your child for the things you would like them to keep doing is a good way to see more positive behaviour in your home. 

Using fair and realistic consequences is also part of building a positive relationship with your child.
rows.media_title: How it helped a parent like you
rows.quiz_1_question: The next time your child cannot follow instructions, can you use a fair consequence in a calm way?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: That's okay. Keep trying. It will get easier in time. You can start by considering smaller behaviours that your child struggles with and planning a fair consequence in advance so you're ready. Remember to take a pause to calm down before you respond.
